abstract.p: Steven A Ludsin letter on April 1 article reminiscing about Sunday dinners with family

block.p: ''Bringing Back the Sunday Dinner'' (April 1) hit home. I should say the home I once knew.

Sundays were family visiting days. Either our aunts, uncles, cousins and friends came to our house or we went to theirs. To this day, I get a bittersweet feeling on a Sunday afternoon when I long for those wonderful days of food, laughter and warmth.
''Bringing Back the Sunday Dinner'' (April 1) hit home. I should say the home I once knew.

Sundays were family visiting days. Either our aunts, uncles, cousins and friends came to our house or we went to theirs. To this day, I get a bittersweet feeling on a Sunday afternoon when I long for those wonderful days of food, laughter and warmth.

My father died 10 years ago and now I realized he was the glue of the family that has come undone primarily over money. Nevertheless, I strive for that sense of camaraderie and that usually takes the form of going out to dinner just to recreate that Sunday feeling.
I know I can't bring it back, but it helps to fill the void by trying. Those Sundays were food for the soul, and that remains with us for life.
Steven A. Ludsin East Hampton, N.Y.
